canonical_explanation.text: In our daily life, we often need to separate mixtures to obtain pure substances or to remove unwanted materials. Different methods of separation are used depending on the properties of the substances in the mixture. Common methods include handpicking, winnowing, sieving, threshing, sedimentation, decantation, filtration, and evaporation. The choice of method depends on the differences in properties such as size, weight, and solubility of the components.
rules: Handpicking is used to separate slightly larger impurities from a mixture by hand.
Winnowing uses wind to separate lighter husk from heavier grain.
Sieving separates particles of different sizes using a sieve with small holes.
Threshing separates grain from stalks by beating or using machines.
Sedimentation allows heavy particles to settle at the bottom of water.
Decantation is pouring off clear liquid after sedimentation without disturbing the sediment.
Filtration separates insoluble solids from liquids using a filter paper or cloth.
Evaporation is used to obtain a dissolved solid from a solution by heating.
A saturated solution cannot dissolve any more solute at a given temperature.
An unsaturated solution can dissolve more solute at a given temperature.

questions.question_text: Why do we need to separate substances from mixtures?

options.text: To obtain useful components or remove unwanted substances
To change the colour of the mixture
To increase the amount of mixture

questions.explanation_correct: We separate substances from mixtures to obtain useful components or to remove harmful or unwanted substances. For example, we separate stones from rice before cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Separation does not make the mixture heavier, change its colour, or increase its amount. The purpose is to obtain useful substances or remove unwanted ones.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Salt dissolved in water is a mixture of two substances — salt and water. A mixture contains two or more substances mixed together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pure water, a gold ring (pure gold), and a diamond are single substances. Salt dissolved in water contains two substances mixed together, making it a mixture.

questions.question_text: What is the method of removing stones from rice by hand called?
questions.explanation_correct: Handpicking is the method of removing unwanted substances (like stones) from a mixture by picking them out by hand. It is used when the impurities are few and clearly visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing uses wind, sieving uses a sieve, and filtration uses a filter. Removing stones from rice by hand is called handpicking.

questions.question_text: Which method uses wind to separate lighter particles from heavier ones?
questions.explanation_correct: Winnowing is the method of separating lighter particles (like husk) from heavier ones (like grain) using wind. The lighter particles are blown away while the heavier ones fall down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sieving separates by size using a sieve, threshing separates grain from stalks by beating, and handpicking removes impurities by hand. Only winnowing uses wind for separation.

questions.question_text: Which method is used to separate grain from its stalks after harvesting?
questions.explanation_correct: Threshing is used to separate grain from stalks. It involves beating the stalks or using a threshing machine to loosen the grain from the chaff.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration separates solids from liquids, evaporation converts liquid to gas, and decantation pours off liquid. Threshing is the specific method for separating grain from stalks.

questions.question_text: Sieving is used to separate mixtures based on the difference in:
questions.explanation_correct: Sieving separates a mixture based on the difference in size of particles. Smaller particles pass through the holes of the sieve while larger ones remain on top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sieving does not separate by colour, weight, or shape. It works based on size differences — smaller particles pass through the sieve holes while larger ones are retained.

questions.question_text: Winnowing is used to separate husk from grain.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Winnowing is the traditional method used to separate lighter husk from heavier grain using wind or blowing air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing is indeed used to separate husk from grain. The lighter husk gets carried away by the wind while the heavier grain falls down.

questions.question_text: When muddy water is left undisturbed, the mud settles at the bottom. This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Sedimentation is the process in which heavy particles in a mixture settle down at the bottom when left undisturbed. The settled particles are called sediment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration uses a filter, evaporation converts liquid to gas, and condensation converts gas to liquid. The settling of heavy particles at the bottom is called sedimentation.

questions.question_text: The process of pouring out clear liquid without disturbing the sediment is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Decantation is the process of gently pouring off the clear upper liquid after sedimentation, without disturbing the sediment at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration uses filter paper, evaporation involves heating, and sedimentation is the settling process. Pouring off the clear liquid is specifically called decantation.

questions.question_text: Which method uses a filter paper to separate an insoluble solid from a liquid?
questions.explanation_correct: Filtration uses a filter paper (or cloth) to separate insoluble solid particles from a liquid. The liquid passes through the filter while the solid particles remain on it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation involves heating, winnowing uses wind, and threshing separates grain from stalks. Filtration is the method that uses filter paper to separate insoluble solids from liquids.

questions.question_text: The process of separating insoluble solids from a liquid using a filter paper is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Filtration is the process where a mixture is passed through a filter paper. The liquid passes through as filtrate while the solid remains on the filter paper as residue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct term is filtration. It involves using a filter paper to separate insoluble solid particles from a liquid.

questions.question_text: To obtain salt from salt water, which method should be used?
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is used to obtain salt from salt water. When the water is heated, it turns into water vapour and escapes, leaving behind solid salt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration cannot separate dissolved salt because salt passes through the filter with water. Handpicking and sieving are for solid mixtures. Evaporation is the correct method for obtaining a dissolved solid.

questions.question_text: When water vapour cools down and turns back into liquid water, the process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Condensation is the process by which water vapour cools and changes back into liquid water. It is the reverse of evaporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation is the change from liquid to gas. Sedimentation involves settling of particles. Filtration separates solids from liquids. Condensation is the change from gas back to liquid.

questions.question_text: A solution in which no more solute can dissolve at a given temperature is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A saturated solution is one in which no more solute can be dissolved at a given temperature. If we try to add more solute, it will remain undissolved at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An unsaturated solution can still dissolve more solute. Dilute and concentrated refer to the relative amount of solute. A saturated solution has reached its maximum dissolving capacity at that temperature.

questions.question_text: An unsaturated solution can dissolve more solute.
questions.explanation_correct: True. An unsaturated solution has not reached its maximum dissolving capacity, so more solute can be dissolved in it at that temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Unlike a saturated solution, an unsaturated solution can still dissolve more solute because it has not reached its limit.

questions.question_text: The process of converting a liquid into its vapour by heating is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is the process by which a liquid changes into vapour when heated. This method is used to obtain dissolved solids from solutions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is evaporation. This process converts liquid into vapour, and is commonly used to obtain salt from sea water.

questions.question_text: At a construction site, sand and gravel are separated using:
questions.explanation_correct: Sieving is used to separate sand from gravel at construction sites. The sand, being smaller, passes through the holes of the sieve while the larger gravel pieces remain on top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing uses wind and is for grain. Handpicking is too slow for large quantities. Evaporation is for liquids. Sieving separates particles by size, which is ideal for sand and gravel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities involves separation of substances?
questions.explanation_correct: Churning milk to get butter is a separation process where cream (fat) is separated from milk. The other options involve mixing substances together, not separating them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixing sugar in tea, adding colour to water, and dissolving salt are all mixing processes. Only churning milk to get butter involves separating a component (butter) from the mixture (milk).

questions.question_text: In water purification, after sedimentation, the next step is usually:
questions.explanation_correct: After sedimentation, decantation or filtration is performed to separate the clear water from the settled sediment. Decantation pours off the clear water, while filtration passes it through a filter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After sedimentation, the next logical step is decantation (pouring off clear water) or filtration (passing through a filter). Winnowing and threshing are for grain, and evaporation removes all water.

questions.question_text: What happens when you keep adding sugar to a glass of water and stirring?

options.text: All the sugar will always dissolve no matter how much is added
After some time, sugar will stop dissolving and settle at the bottom
The water will turn into sugar

questions.explanation_correct: After adding enough sugar, the water becomes a saturated solution and can dissolve no more sugar. Any additional sugar will settle at the bottom undissolved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water has a limit to how much sugar it can dissolve. Once it becomes saturated, extra sugar remains undissolved at the bottom. Water does not turn into sugar, and sugar does not evaporate.

questions.question_text: A farmer has harvested wheat. Which sequence of methods should he use to first separate the grain from stalks, then remove the husk, and finally remove small stones?
questions.explanation_correct: First, threshing separates grain from stalks. Then winnowing separates lighter husk from heavier grain using wind. Finally, handpicking removes small stones that are similar in size to grain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct sequence is threshing (separate grain from stalks), winnowing (remove husk using wind), and handpicking (remove stones by hand). This follows the logical order of grain processing.

questions.question_text: Priya has a mixture of sand and salt. She adds water to dissolve the salt and then pours the mixture through a filter paper. What will remain on the filter paper?
questions.explanation_correct: Sand is insoluble in water and cannot pass through the filter paper, so it remains on the filter paper. Salt, being dissolved in water, passes through the filter paper along with the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt dissolves in water and passes through the filter with the water as filtrate. Only the insoluble sand remains on the filter paper as residue.

questions.question_text: To separate a mixture of sand and water, Ravi lets the sand settle and then carefully pours the water into another container. Which two processes did Ravi use?
questions.explanation_correct: First, Ravi allowed the sand to settle down (sedimentation). Then he poured off the clear water (decantation). These two processes are often used together to separate insoluble heavy solids from liquids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Letting sand settle is sedimentation, and pouring off the clear water is decantation. These are two complementary processes for separating heavy insoluble substances from water.

questions.question_text: How is common salt obtained from sea water in salt pans?

options.text: By evaporation of sea water using sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: Common salt is obtained from sea water by evaporation. Sea water is collected in large, shallow pans and left in the sun. The water evaporates, leaving behind solid salt crystals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration cannot separate dissolved salt from water. Sedimentation is for settling insoluble particles. Winnowing is for grain and husk. Evaporation using sunlight is the method used in salt pans.

questions.question_text: Anu has a mixture of rice and dal of different sizes. Which method should she use to separate them?
questions.explanation_correct: Sieving can separate rice and dal if they are of different sizes. The smaller grains will pass through the sieve holes while the larger ones remain on top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing separates by weight using wind, which would not work well here. Filtration and evaporation involve liquids. Sieving separates particles of different sizes, making it ideal for rice and dal.

questions.question_text: In the kitchen, tea leaves are separated from tea using a strainer. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Using a tea strainer is an example of filtration. The liquid tea passes through the small holes of the strainer, while the solid tea leaves are left behind, similar to filter paper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A tea strainer works like a filter — the liquid passes through while solids remain. This is filtration, not evaporation, sedimentation, or winnowing.

questions.question_text: Meena dissolved sugar in water and then wants to get the sugar back. What should she do?

options.text: Heat the solution to evaporate the water

questions.explanation_correct: Since sugar is dissolved in water, it cannot be separated by filtration or sedimentation. Meena should heat the solution so the water evaporates, leaving behind solid sugar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dissolved sugar passes through filters and does not settle by sedimentation. Winnowing is for grain. Only evaporation can recover a dissolved solid from a solution.

questions.question_text: Rahul makes a sugar solution and keeps adding sugar until no more dissolves. He then heats the solution. What will happen?

options.text: More sugar will dissolve because solubility increases with temperature
All the sugar will come out of the solution
The water will turn into sugar

questions.explanation_correct: Heating a saturated solution increases its capacity to dissolve more solute. So, the undissolved sugar at the bottom will dissolve when the solution is heated, making it unsaturated again.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating increases the solubility of most solids in water. So a saturated solution becomes unsaturated when heated, allowing more sugar to dissolve. Water does not turn into sugar.

questions.question_text: Which separation method would be best for separating a mixture of iron filings and sand?
questions.explanation_correct: A magnet can attract iron filings but not sand. Moving a magnet through the mixture will pull out the iron filings, separating them from the sand effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing requires a weight difference, filtration needs a liquid, and evaporation needs a solution. A magnet is the best choice because iron is magnetic and sand is not.

questions.question_text: Sieving can be used to separate flour from bran.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Flour particles are smaller than bran particles. When sieved, flour passes through the sieve holes while the larger bran pieces remain on top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Sieving works based on particle size. Fine flour passes through the sieve while coarser bran stays on top, effectively separating them.

questions.question_text: A student has muddy water. She filters it through filter paper. The clear water that passes through is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The clear liquid that passes through the filter paper is called the filtrate. The solid particles left on the filter paper are called the residue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Residue is the solid left on the filter paper. Sediment is what settles at the bottom during sedimentation. The clear liquid that passes through is called the filtrate.

questions.question_text: Sea water is left in shallow pans under the sun. The water evaporates and ___ is left behind.
questions.explanation_correct: When sea water evaporates in salt pans, the dissolved salt is left behind as solid crystals. This is how common salt is obtained from the sea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sea water contains dissolved salt. When the water evaporates, the salt remains behind as solid crystals.

questions.question_text: Which method would be most practical for separating a large quantity of wheat from chaff?
questions.explanation_correct: Winnowing is the most practical method for separating large quantities of wheat from chaff. The lighter chaff is blown away by wind while the heavier wheat grains fall down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Handpicking would be too slow for large quantities. Filtration and evaporation involve liquids. Winnowing efficiently uses wind to separate lighter chaff from heavier grain.

questions.question_text: Neha adds 5 spoons of salt to warm water and stirs. All the salt dissolves. She then adds 2 more spoons and some salt remains undissolved. The solution after adding the extra 2 spoons is:
questions.explanation_correct: Since some salt remains undissolved at the bottom, the solution has reached its maximum dissolving capacity and is now saturated. No more salt can dissolve in it at that temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When solute remains undissolved at the bottom, the solution is saturated. An unsaturated solution would dissolve all the salt. The presence of undissolved salt confirms saturation.

questions.question_text: Your mother asks you to separate small stones from pulses (dal). The stones and dal are roughly the same size. Which method would you use?
questions.explanation_correct: When stones and dal are roughly the same size, sieving and winnowing will not work effectively. Handpicking is the best method, as you can visually identify and remove stones by hand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sieving works only when sizes differ significantly. Winnowing works when weights differ greatly. Since stones and dal are similar in size, handpicking is the most suitable method.

questions.question_text: Which sequence correctly describes the process of purifying muddy water at home?
questions.explanation_correct: First, let the mud settle (sedimentation). Then pour off the clear water (decantation). Finally, filter the water through a cloth or filter paper (filtration) to remove remaining fine particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is sedimentation first (mud settles), then decantation (pour off clear water), then filtration (remove fine particles). This progressively removes impurities.

questions.question_text: Evaporation can be used to separate salt dissolved in water.
questions.explanation_correct: True. When salt water is heated, the water evaporates leaving behind solid salt. This is how salt is commonly obtained from sea water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Evaporation removes the liquid (water) by converting it to vapour, leaving behind the dissolved solid (salt).

questions.question_text: A mixture contains sand, salt, and iron filings. To separate all three, which sequence of methods should be used?

options.text: Use a magnet, then add water and filter, then evaporate
Filter, then evaporate, then use a magnet

questions.explanation_correct: First, use a magnet to remove iron filings (only iron is attracted to magnets). Then add water to dissolve salt, and filter to separate sand. Finally, evaporate the salt water to get salt. Each step uses a different property of the components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct sequence uses different properties: magnetic property (iron), solubility (salt dissolves in water, sand does not), and evaporation (to recover dissolved salt).

questions.question_text: Why can filtration NOT be used to separate salt from salt water?

options.text: Because salt is dissolved in water and its particles pass through the filter paper
Because filter paper dissolves in salt water
Because salt changes colour during filtration

questions.explanation_correct: Salt is dissolved in water, meaning it breaks into very tiny particles that are much smaller than the pores of filter paper. So both salt and water pass through the filter together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filter paper does not dissolve in salt water, and salt does not change colour. The reason is that dissolved salt particles are too small to be caught by filter paper, so they pass through with the water.

questions.question_text: Identify the property of the mixture components that is used for each method: (i) Winnowing uses difference in ___ (ii) Sieving uses difference in ___
questions.explanation_correct: Winnowing works because lighter particles (husk) are blown away by wind while heavier particles (grain) fall down — using difference in weight. Sieving separates particles that pass through or are retained by the holes — using difference in size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing separates by weight (lighter husk vs heavier grain) and sieving separates by size (small vs large particles). These are the key properties each method relies on.

questions.question_text: Amit heats a beaker of salt water. As the water level decreases, he notices white crystals forming. Which process is responsible for the formation of these crystals?
questions.explanation_correct: Evaporation is causing the water to turn into vapour and escape. As water decreases, the salt becomes more concentrated and eventually forms solid crystals when there is not enough water to keep it dissolved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Condensation would form water droplets, not crystals. Filtration and sedimentation are not involved. Evaporation removes water, causing dissolved salt to come out as solid crystals.

questions.question_text: Two students prepare sugar solutions. Student A dissolves 3 spoons of sugar in cold water. Student B dissolves 5 spoons in the same amount of hot water. Both solutions are clear. Which statement is most likely true?

options.text: Hot water can dissolve more sugar than cold water
Cold water can dissolve more sugar than hot water

questions.explanation_correct: Hot water dissolved more sugar (5 spoons) compared to cold water (3 spoons). This shows that increasing temperature increases the solubility of sugar in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the hot water dissolved more sugar, it demonstrates that solubility increases with temperature for most solids. Temperature does affect solubility.

questions.question_text: A flour mill uses a machine with vibrating mesh screens with holes of different sizes. This is an application of which separation method?
questions.explanation_correct: Vibrating mesh screens with holes of different sizes separate particles by size, which is exactly how sieving works. Finer flour passes through while larger particles or impurities are retained.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing uses wind, threshing separates grain from stalks, and handpicking removes items by hand. Mesh screens with holes are an industrial form of sieving.

questions.question_text: In a filtration experiment, a student pours a mixture of chalk and water through filter paper. She labels the solid on the filter paper as X and the clear liquid that passes through as Y. What are X and Y?
questions.explanation_correct: In filtration, the solid left on the filter paper is called the residue (X = chalk), and the clear liquid that passes through is called the filtrate (Y = water).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solid remaining on filter paper is always called the residue, and the liquid passing through is the filtrate. Do not confuse these with sedimentation terms (sediment) or solution terms (solute/solvent).

questions.question_text: Sita has a saturated salt solution at room temperature. She wants to dissolve more salt without adding more water. What should she do?
questions.explanation_correct: Heating the solution increases its capacity to dissolve more solute. A saturated solution at room temperature becomes unsaturated when heated, allowing more salt to dissolve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stirring faster does not increase solubility, only the speed of dissolution. Cooling decreases solubility. Filter paper is for filtration. Heating is the way to increase solubility.

questions.question_text: Which separation method is used in a water treatment plant to remove large floating objects like leaves and twigs?
questions.explanation_correct: Water treatment plants use screens (large sieves) to remove big floating objects like leaves and twigs. This is a form of sieving used at a large scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation removes water, sedimentation settles fine particles, and condensation forms liquid from vapour. Screening/sieving removes large objects based on size.

questions.question_text: Water drops are seen on the outside of a cold glass of lemonade on a hot day. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Water vapour in the warm air condenses (turns to liquid) when it comes in contact with the cold surface of the glass. This is condensation — the reverse of evaporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not evaporation (liquid to gas) but condensation (gas to liquid). The cold glass cools the water vapour in the surrounding air, causing it to turn into liquid water droplets.

questions.question_text: Explain why winnowing would NOT work for separating a mixture of sand and gravel.

options.text: Both sand and gravel are too heavy for wind to carry either one
Sand and gravel have the same colour
Sand and gravel are the same size

questions.explanation_correct: Winnowing relies on wind blowing away lighter particles. Both sand and gravel are heavy, so wind cannot carry either of them away effectively. Sieving (based on size difference) would be the correct method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winnowing fails here not because of colour or size, but because both materials are too heavy for wind to separate them. Winnowing works best when one component is very light (like husk).

questions.question_text: The solid left on the filter paper after filtration is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The residue is the solid substance that remains on the filter paper after filtration. The liquid that passes through is called the filtrate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In filtration, the solid left behind on the filter paper is called the residue. The clear liquid that passes through is the filtrate.

questions.question_text: Rohan prepares a sugar solution that can still dissolve more sugar. He then cools it in a refrigerator. What is likely to happen?

options.text: Some sugar may come out of the solution as crystals

questions.explanation_correct: Cooling a solution decreases the solubility of most solids. If the solution was close to being saturated at room temperature, cooling it may cause some sugar to come out of solution and form crystals at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cooling decreases solubility, so less sugar can stay dissolved. Some dissolved sugar may crystallize out. Water does not evaporate in a refrigerator. The solution will change because temperature affects solubility.
